title: Office of Displaced Designers

author: Shareen Elnaschie, Office of Displaced Designers

segmentation: Hello everyone, thank you for the introduction and for the invitation to be here.
Weather in Amish bone racing in Middle America or the annual repair festival of the mosque in Jenna and Molly, collective participation has been at the center of many communities lives for centuries.
The power of this simple idea lies in its ability to draw all kinds of different people together across generations to work towards a shared goal to problem solve, to learn.
And in the process, to contribute to more inclusive SoC.
Our primary hope for the future of architecture is to once again put collaborative practice at the heart of shaping the built environment.
Capitalizing on the opportunities that brings for skill sharing and learning.
I'm using architecture as a driver for social cohesion and this really forms part of the foundation of our work.
Office of Displaced Designers is based in Mytilini on the Greek island of Lesbos and we are in architecture and design organization and a UK registered charitable fund.
That primarily facilitates skill sharing.
We operate as the collaborative.

And we support multidisciplinary projects either relating to or impacting on the built Environment Protection issues, social cohesion, integration or cultural understanding, and through these design projects, we try to provide professional development training opportunities for both displaced persons and locals, either those who have a background in in creativity or design, all those who've got really keen interest to learn new skills and a design related field.

Because of the context we're working in, we have to take quite a Broadview of architecture and design is and we've been trying to develop our working methods to be as flexible and accommodating of restrictive shifting needs and interests that we find and the part of the reason we need to be so flexible is because of where we are geographically.
Lesbos, which is circled in red, is the largest of the Aegean islands close to the coast.
West Coast of Turkey and due to its location and one of the primary migration routes, it's really been on the frontline of receiving migrants and refugees over the past few years.
Although new arrivals have decreased over the last year, there now stop for much longer periods of time.
They're not transitioning as quickly as they were before this influx and the associated issues that it brings us had quite significant impact across the region.

Compounding the already quite harsh economic realities of Greece, including sustained high unemployment rates, which is somewhere around 24%, I think 8% is the average for the Europe as a whole and degraded tourism industry.
The decline in bookings on Lesvos alone is anywhere between 50 to 80% drop depending who you ask.
Typically tourism is 20% of national GDP, and for the islands that's even more significant were also challenged to be working in this kind of unclaimed space between.
Emergency aid and sustainable development.
Well, this is kind of struggle to balance.

A very reactionary short term intervention need with longer term strategic planning, which brings us to our second hope or objective I guess for the future, which is to begin to test ways in which we might be able to at least start to bridge this gap between Aid and Development, or at least to maximize the collaborative and participatory ways in which established organisations are delivering aid in a way that can be more mutually beneficial to the host community.
When we first began thinking about this idea, it was just after the EU Turkey deal had come into effect.
So the number of new arrivals have been significantly reduced, but people were forced stuck in Limbo for undetermined periods of time.
As mentioned in the introduction, I've we were based at Carrot Happy Camp.

I was a long term volunteer with an NGO called Humanitarian Support Agency and once we were doing an education needs assessment, we met all kinds of people with a really broad range of creative skills and backgrounds.
The thing that united all of them was that they were really bored and they missed their work.

They still found themselves in this culture of dependency that was having very significant detrimental effects on their mental well being, and although there were some activities offered within the camps, the kind of level autonomy that was offered to them in terms of how these programs were arranged and managed and what they focused on was very limited.
So six months ago we launched a pilot project with a small group of creatives from Carrot Happy Camp.

To kind of test the interest levels in to discuss what an agenda for a group like this might be, what was emphasized from that experiment was the importance of having a place of work to go to, and that they really appreciated the kind of collaborative and professional nature of the work that we were all trying to do.
It also highlighted a really strong desire.
To have a purpose outside of the camp and that they felt this kind of sense of isolation from the local Greek community.
Like the population we encountered at Karatepe a, there's also a huge amount of creative potential within the local community itself, but limited opportunities for them to express this.
And also few chances for people to engage with the refugee population in a positive way.

The local Contacts combined with what we learned during the pilot project kind of, presented a special opportunity for us to try to Unite the interests of these two groups under the collective umbrella of the creative community.

So how do we work and how we trying to achieve our vision of a more collaborative and ultimately inclusive environment, SoC or office space in mytilini access our base where we facilitate and support variety of different projects and host workshops, classes and events.

Currently we have three main categories of project generators, either the community which can be from the displaced community or the local where ideas are put forward and we try to facilitate their development professional skills sharing where we either approached by individuals that have an idea for a workshop they'd like to run, or we put a call out for a professional to fill the gap that we've identified or commissioned.
Work for example by organisations where we would more typically provide design services and consultancy to make sure that their projects and maximizing.
The potential to engage their target audience through.
More participatory methods.

Whichever group is generated the project we tried to act as the facilitators, we creep participants necessary resource is and fill any gaps, and in all of these scenarios we're really trying to bring or to use education and training as the tool for positive change.

So in addition to any of the kind of planned project outputs, depending on what style or type it is, we also get kind of spinoff projects from participants who want to continue developing a new skill that they've learned.
Or perhaps they come in as a new professional.
At.
Moment we're working on two community initiated projects.
The first was brought to us by a refugee who wants to research the feasibility and most cost effective method providing some kind of some kind of reflector for people walking back from the camps.
The lovers Lesbos roads are very dark and winding.
People drive quite fast, so it's a significant protection issue and the second was identified by the wider refugee community around clothes washing and drying.
So resisting a group of students from Cambridge University who are developing an off grid off grid clothes dryer.
In both these cases were attempting to maximize the opportunities for participation.
So rather than just consultation, we're trying to build in flexibility early on so that users can feedback how the development will.
Will be changed.

Hoping to encourage more of a sense of Co ownership, whether they're kind of more of a client rather than just a consumer, and we're also trying to build in creative opportunities for recording this research.
So three photography and film, for example.
This is the most recent workshop that we ran, which brought together both the displaced and local community to work on a documentary filmmaking workshop.
And this was on centered on three key themes of vulnerability, resilience and self esteem.

It is an intensive five day course and each participant had the opportunity to develop an individual film which range from personal stories of hopes they had for their career, to exploring the built environment, looking at the contrast between the tourist experience and the refugee experience on the island, I think what was most striking for the participants.
Actually, during the discussion stage of this workshop was that.
They came to realize how much they had in similarity in terms of their personal experiences of these.
So even if the external effects causing the vulnerability were different, the way that they experienced resilience and self esteem is very similar.
So it was quite a powerful.
Moving experience for them to learn about the opposite community in this way.
The final example that we are currently working on was commissioned by the Danish Red Cross.
To develop and deliver some recreational spaces next to one of the camps.
Our role in this case was developer, a program that gathered ideas, generated designs and then plan for the work to be delivered through kind of like construction training program.
So it was agreed that we would formalize an existing area that was already being used as an outdoor cinema.
So we're creating some outdoor seating and look looking at creating an outdoor gym.
We run two to three sessions a week, or we are doing still.
On the day typically starts with an information session.
We've taken participants through how to read architectural drawings using handheld power tools.
In some cases, how to use a measuring tape.
So it's a lot of different skills.
People drop in and drop out depending on what else is going on with their asylum claim.
But we now have a cool group that's starting to kind of suggest their own projects.
They're starting to self organize and respond to the environment.
We're working at quite a modest scale.
But I think the most important lesson that we've learned through doing this kind of goes beyond any scale.
And that lesson, which is both simple and perhaps obvious, is that practically everyone wants to contribute positively to society, but there simply aren't the opportunities for everyone to do so.
The top down approach is whether it's paid or development.
Somehow stuck in this mindset of delivering to beneficiaries.
But what if the benefit was inherent in the delivery itself?
Can we ask ourselves the question, how my absolutely maximizing the opportunities for active participation and learning?
Participation I don't think is a nice to have.
It's essential and I think what we really need to remember is that participation is not innovative, it's just normal.
Thank you for your time.
